snippet.textDisplay: I understand this happened 4 years ago now, but reading through these comments made me feel sorry for you. I just want to say I hope you've learned how to respect others more over the internet. If you're going to criticize and belittle people simply for using "your" instead of "you're," or stating that games and movies aren't as accurately relatable in their opinion, then you must be leading a sad life. No one deserves to be so belittled simply for one grammatical error. I suggest you gain a better sense of maturity, and correct people's mistakes with a sense of respect and kindness. Otherwise your social reputation will continue to go downhill, and you'll leave the impression that you must lead a very sad life.

snippet.textDisplay: Haven't I already responded to a similar, inane comment?  Very astute observation there.  Next you'll be telling me GTA: Vice City wasn't inspired by Scarface.  It doesn't matter where the influence comes from.  In fact, it's often better if its based on outside mediums.  In this case it was direct plagiarism as the design was exactly the same (which is understandable given the iconic design of the Terminator).  Now go back to school and don't darken my doorway again.

snippet.textDisplay: @masterplusmargarita Every decision I made felt so... decisive. When I got out alive with only losing Thane I was like, " Oh god yes!" This is what makes mass effect awesome.
snippet.textOriginal: @masterplusmargarita Every decision I made felt so... decisive. When I got out alive with only losing Thane I was like, " Oh god yes!" This is what makes mass effect awesome.

snippet.textDisplay:
For me, the Suicide Mission sequence is the best final sequence in video game history, and I'm not one to say that kind of thing. It felt so impacting, so raw, yet so elegant and decisive. Every choice had you wondering, and every cutscene had you on end. ME2 is not my favourite game (I would put it in my top 20, but not in the top 10), because it had quite a bunch of plotholes down the way, but the Suicide Mission was wonderful.

Both the ME's are awesome. Let's hope 3 is even better.
snippet.textOriginal:
For me, the Suicide Mission sequence is the best final sequence in video game history, and I'm not one to say that kind of thing. It felt so impacting, so raw, yet so elegant and decisive. Every choice had you wondering, and every cutscene had you on end. ME2 is not my favourite game (I would put it in my top 20, but not in the top 10), because it had quite a bunch of plotholes down the way, but the Suicide Mission was wonderful.

Both the ME's are awesome. Let's hope 3 is even better.

snippet.textDisplay:
@SupraDarky 
The reaction that was given when they announced a few things...

>At least one level has to be big enough for Shepard to fight using a 50-foot tall Cerberus mech.
...what the hell?

>A giant thresher maw takes down a Reaper during a train sequence on Tuchanka
...guys, seriously, stop--

>Cerberus hit teams with ninja sword-wielding assassins and mechs trying to kill you regardless of what you did in ME2.
Goddamnit Walters...

>Making the game more accessible for new players...
wat?

snippet.textDisplay: Mass Effect 2 has the greatest storyline and the most epic ending out of any other game I've played (In my opinion)

snippet.textDisplay: @animefanatic777 If you have a sufficient PC, it's quite regularly below 10$ on steam. Just wait for another EA week. I have not played Uncharted, but Mass Effect 2 is the most epic, dramatic gaming experience I have ever witnessed. It's not the "best game ever" by several points, but the tension and atmosphere it delivers are astounding. I connect many of my most emotional experiences in a game with Mass Effect 2, especially the suicide mission.
snippet.textOriginal: @animefanatic777 If you have a sufficient PC, it's quite regularly below 10$ on steam. Just wait for another EA week. I have not played Uncharted, but Mass Effect 2 is the most epic, dramatic gaming experience I have ever witnessed. It's not the "best game ever" by several points, but the tension and atmosphere it delivers are astounding. I connect many of my most emotional experiences in a game with Mass Effect 2, especially the suicide mission.

snippet.textDisplay:
Bender: Sir, I volunteer for a suicide mission.
[Bender's antenna stops flashing and he bangs his head with his knuckles]
Bender: Cut it out!
Captain Zapp Brannigan: You're a brave robot, son. But when I'm in command every mission's a suicide mission.

snippet.textDisplay: @SupraDarky DA2 is well polished and has high presentation values much like Mass Effect.  It will keep you entertained until the end, but there are some serious flaws to it.  Re-used environments and enemies are a big one, along with a fumbled final chapter.  I do believe, however, that EA is only partially responsible for the mistakes in the final product.  A good storyline should have been written before the game was even started, so EA's rushing shouldn't be the cause to that blunder.
snippet.textOriginal: @SupraDarky DA2 is well polished and has high presentation values much like Mass Effect.  It will keep you entertained until the end, but there are some serious flaws to it.  Re-used environments and enemies are a big one, along with a fumbled final chapter.  I do believe, however, that EA is only partially responsible for the mistakes in the final product.  A good storyline should have been written before the game was even started, so EA's rushing shouldn't be the cause to that blunder.

snippet.textDisplay:
Mass Effect 3 has been pushed back, I'm alright with it as long as it delivers. I heard some pretty bad things about Dragon Age 2 and how EA might have rushed them to release it. Hopefully EA doesn't have a negative influence on ME3.

This is one of the few games where I bought some DLC (Lair of the Shadow Broker and the last one which was too short). I'm a big fan of this series.
